problem_data.brief_description: compute the sum of two numbers
problem_data.description:
Write a function called compute_sum that takes two parameters and returns their sum.

Example calls:

  • compute_sum(2, 3) => 5
  • compute_sum(4, -11) => -7
  • compute_sum(42, 0) => 42

problem_data.brief_description: FInd the unique number in a list of odd number of integers.
problem_data.description: Write a function called unique_integer that returns the unique number in a list.

problem_data.brief_description: compute the product of two numbers
problem_data.description:
Write a function called computeProduct that takes two parameters and returns their product.

Example calls:

  • computeProduct(2, 3) => 6
  • computeProduct(4, -11) => -44
  • computeProduct(42, 0) => 0

problem_data.brief_description: Shift a character ahead by a given number of letters
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a single character and an int key as parameters, and then shifts the character ahead by the given number of spots, wrapping around from z to a. For simplicity, assume all input chars are lower-case letters. For example: 
shiftChar('a', 4) => 'e'
shiftChar('z', 1) => 'a'
shiftChar('z', 26) => 'z'
problem_data.skeleton:

    # code goes here

problem_data.brief_description: Shift a character backwards, wrapping around.
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a single character and an int key as parameters, and then shifts the character backwards by the given number of letters, wrapping around from a back around z. For simplicity, assume all input chars are lower-case letters.
Note that this it is harder to shift backwards than forwards. You may need to add extra multiple of 26 so that you don't get back a negative value when subtracting off the key.
For example: 
unshiftChar('a', 4) => 'w'
unshiftChar('z', 1) => 'y'
unshiftChar('z', 26) => 'z'
problem_data.skeleton:

problem_data.brief_description: Check if all instances of string a appear before string b.
problem_data.description:
Check if all instances of string a appear before string b. Return True if all instances of A are before B. 
aBeforeB("cats cats cats dogs dogs", "cats", "dogs") -> True
aBeforeB("cats cats dogs cats dogs", "cats", "dogs") -> False
aBeforeB("dogs cats cats cats dogs", "cats", "dogs") -> False
aBeforeB("cats dogs", "cats", "dogs") -> True

problem_data.brief_description: Return true if the function parameter is less than 10
problem_data.description:
Write a function called lessThan10 that takes one parameter and returns true if the parameter is strictly less than 10, and false otherwise. For example: 
lessThan10(9) => True
lessThan10(10) => False
lessThan10(11) => False
problem_data.skeleton:

problem_data.brief_description: Is a number positive and less than 10?
problem_data.description:
Write a method that takes an int as a parameter and returns true if the parameter is both positive (i.e. greater than 0) and also strictly less than 10. For example: 
positiveLessThan10(10) => False
positiveLessThan10(-5) => False
positiveLessThan10(5) => True

Write a method called isBetween that takes three parameters and returns true if the first number is between the second two, inclusively, and false otherwise. 
isBetween(3, 3, 3) should return true
isBetween(4, 7, 9) should return false
isBetween(2, 1, 3) should return true
isBetween(2, 3, 1) should return true

problem_data.brief_description: Is the number Prime
problem_data.description:
Return True for prime numbers or False for numbers that are not prime. 
isPrime(5)=> True
isPrime(11)=> True
isPrime(8)=> False
isPrime(1949)=> True
isPrime(15)=> False
isPrime(51)=> False

problem_data.brief_description: Find the largest number.
problem_data.description:
Return the largest number in the group. Don't cheat and use max function! 
    max(1,8,0)=>8
    max(-1,-5,-6)=>-1
    max(100, 60, 1000)=>1000
    max(1, 1, 0)=>1

problem_data.brief_description: Count the number of As in a string
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a string and returns the number of "a"s. 
countA("This is a string") -> 1
countA("Oranges are not apples") -> 3
countA("To be or not to be") -> 0

test_case_data_list.input: "a horse is a horse is a"

problem_data.brief_description: Count all instances of a given character
problem_data.description:
Count all instances of a given character in the string. 
countX("x1x2x3x4", 'x') -> 4
countX("finding all the instances of n", 'n') -> 5
countX("There are none of that letter", 'z') -> 0

problem_data.brief_description: Replace the first character in the string.
problem_data.description:
Replace the first character in the string with c. 
replace1("a") -> "c"
replace1("a goes to c") -> "c goes to c"
replace1("bats are not cats") -> "cats are not cats"
replace1("") -> ""

problem_data.brief_description: Replace all of the given characters with c
problem_data.description:
Replace all of the given characters with c. 
replaceC("replace the x with a c", "x") -> "replace the c with a c"
replaceC("This is not aaa work", "a") -> "This is not ccc work"
replaceC("To b or not to b for I want to b the world", "c") -> "To c or not to c for I want to c the world"

test_case_data_list.input: "To b or not to b for I want to b the world", "b"
test_case_data_list.output: "To c or not to c for I want to c the world"

Replace all instances of ch1 with ch2. 
replaceX("abvdef", "v","c")->"abcdef"
replaceX("xreaspbaxpoinb", "a","i")->"xreispbixpoinb"
replaceX("Four score and seven years ago", "e","t")->"Four scort and stvtn ytars ago"

problem_data.brief_description: Replace chars between two indices with given string
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes four parameters (a string s1, two ints, i and j, and another string s1) and replaces all of the characters of s1 between i (inclusive) and j (exclusive) with s2. If j is equal to or longer than the length of s1, replace everything in s1 from i to the end of the string with s2. For example: 
replaceAtIndex('knox college', 4, 10, ' villa') => 'knox village'
replaceAtIndex('knox college', 5, 100, 'rocks') => 'knox rocks'
replaceAtIndex('monmouth college', 0, 100, '') => ''

problem_data.brief_description: Return true the second string is in the main string
problem_data.description:
Return True if s2 is in s1 and False if it is not. 
isIn("cats and dogs", "t") -> True
isIn("cats and dogs", "dog") -> True
isIn("cats and dogs", "pet") -> False
isIn("cats and dogs", "ts and") -> True

problem_data.brief_description: Return true if the second string is not in the first string.
problem_data.description:
Return true if the second string is not in the first string. "Use not in". 
isNotIn("I is not in team", "i") -> False
isNotIn("I is not in team", "g") -> True
isNotIn("team", "i") -> True
isNotIn("I is not in team", "teams") -> True

problem_data.brief_description: Count the most common DNA base pairs
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a String that consists only of the capital letters A, C, G, and T, and returns the number of times each letter occurs. You can return multiple values by putting them in parentheses, like this: 
return (1, 2, 8, 4)
Be sure to return the counts in the order ACGT. For example: 
countBasePairs('GATTACA') => (3, 1, 1, 2)
countBasePairs('') => (0, 0, 0, 0)
countBasePairs('GGTCAGGCCCCT' => (1, 5, 4, 2)

problem_data.brief_description: Check if a String is a DNA string of base pairs.
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a string as a parameter, and returns True if the string is a DNA string (i.e. only contains the capital letters A, C, G, T), and False otherwise. A DNA string must be at least 1 character in length, so the empty string is not a DNA string. For example: 
isDNAString('GATTACA') => True
isDNAString('GATTACA 2: The Return of Ethan Hawke') => False
isDNAString('') => False

problem_data.brief_description: Count the number of genes in a DNA string.
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes strings named seq and gene as parameters, and returns the number of times that gene occurs in seq. For example: 
countGenes('GATTACA', 'ATT') => 1
countGenes('ATCGGATCGGAAAATTACCG', 'ATCGG') => 2
countGenes('ATCGGATCGGAAAATTACCG', 'TTTTTTT') => 0
problem_data.skeleton:

problem_data.brief_description: Find the sequences that occur between two genes.
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes three parameters: a sequence of DNA called seq, a gene called g1, and a gene called g2. Return all of the strings that occur between an occurrence of g1 and the nearest occurrence of g2 that comes after it. If g1 occurs without g2, return the empty string. If there are extra occurrences of g2, use the first one. If there are extra occurrences of g1, use the last one. For example: 
betweenGenes('ATAATCGTGGCCA', 'AAT', 'GCCA') => 'CGTG'
betweenGenes('CGTGATCGCAATGGGGCAGTC', 'AT', 'CA') => 'CGGGGG'
betweenGenes('ATAATCGTGGCCA', 'AAT', 'GCCA') => 'CGTG'
problem_data.skeleton:

problem_data.brief_description: Sum all the numbers in the list
problem_data.description:
Write a function that returns the sum of all elements of the list. Do not use the sum() function. 
    sumIt([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])=> 21
    sumIt([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])=> -21
    sumIt([-1, 2, -3, 4, -5, 6])=> 3

problem_data.brief_description: Write a program that takes a list and supplies the average.
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and returns the average. Do not use the sum() function. 
    avgIt([5,5,5,5])=>5
    avgIt([5,15,10,20,25])=>15
    avgIt([3,6,0,9])=>4.5

problem_data.brief_description: Compute the max of a list
problem_data.description:
Write a program that takes a list and finds the maximum element. Do not use the max() function. 
    maxList([5,5,5,5])=>5
    maxList([5,15,10,20,25])=>25
    maxList([-3,-2,-1,-6,-9,-11])=>-1

problem_data.brief_description: Sum the elements of a list whose value is over 10.
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and returns the sum of the values that are greater than 10. Do not use the max() function. 
    sumOver10([5,6,7,8,9])=>0
    sumOver10([19,11,0,10,8])=>30
    sumOver10([-3,-2,-1,-6,-9,-11, 57])=>57

problem_data.brief_description: Sum all values over a parameter N
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and an int n and returns the sum of the values that are greater than n. 
    sumOverN([5,6,7,8,9], 7)=>17
    sumOverN([19,11,0,10,8], 11)=>19
    sumOverN([-3,-2,-1,-6,-9,-11,57], -2)=>56

problem_data.brief_description: Return the index of the max value
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and returns the index (index, not the value) of the maximum element. If the max value occurs multiple times, return the index of the first occurrence. Do not use the max() function. The max of an empty list is undefined, so your function can crash if given an empty list. 
    maxIndex([5,5,5,5])=>0
    maxIndex([5,15,10,20,25])=>4
    maxIndex([-3,-2,-1,-6,-9,-11])=>2

problem_data.brief_description: Find the index of the longest string
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of strings and returns the index of the longest string. If there are multiple longest strings, return the index of the first. If the list is empty, your code may crash. 
    longestStringIndex(['dog', 'cat', 'a', 'ab'])=>0
    longestStringIndex(['', 'a', 'ab', 'abc']) => 3
    longestStringIndex(['knox', 'college', 'flunk', 'day'])=>1

problem_data.brief_description: Count number of strings longer than given parameter
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of strings and a string, and returns the number of strings in the list that are longer than the given string. 
    countLongerStrings(['dog', 'cat', 'a', 'ab'], 'z')=>3
    countLongerStrings(['', 'a', 'ab', 'abc'], 'abcd') => 0
    countLongerStrings(['knox', 'college', 'flunk', 'day'], 'april')=>1

problem_data.brief_description: Count the number of values that are above average
problem_data.description:
Write a program that takes two lists of ints as parameters, and returns the number of elements in the second list that are greater than the average of the first list. Do not use the sum() function. 
    numAboveAverage([5,5,5,5], [3,4,5,6,7])=>2
    numAboveAverage([5,15,10,20,25], [34, 12, 19, -1])=>2
    numAboveAverage([5, 7], [])=>0

problem_data.brief_description: Count number of times 7 occurs right before 9 in list
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints as a parameter and returns the number of times that 7 occurs directly before 9 in the list. For example: 
    count79([1,2,7,8,9]) => 0
    count79([1,2,7,9,8,9,7,9]) => 2
    count79([7,9,7,9,7,9,7]) => 3

problem_data.brief_description: Count num times two ints occur in order in given list
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and two ints, N and M, and returns the number of times NM occurs in order in the given list. For example: 
    countNM([1,2,3,4,5], 2, 1) => 0
    countNM([1,2,3,4,5], 1, 2) => 1
    countNM([1,2,1,2,1], 1, 2) => 2
    countNM([-3, 8, 9, 12, 8, 12, 9], 12, 8) => 1

problem_data.brief_description: Count num times NM or MN occur in a given list
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and two ints, N and M, and returns the number of times NM or MN occurs in order in the given list. For example: 
    countNMorMN([1,2,3,4,5], 2, 1) => 1
    countNMorMN([1,2,3,4,5], 1, 2) => 1
    countNMorMN([1,2,1,2,1], 1, 2) => 4
    countNMorMN([-3, 8, 9, 12, 8, 12, 9], 12, 8) => 2

problem_data.brief_description: Count the number of times each value occurs
Count num values greater by index in two lists
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes two lists of ints that are the same length, and returns the number of values in the second list that are greater than the value at the same index in the first list. For example: 
    numGreaterAtIndex([1,2,3], [7, 8, 9]) => 3
    numGreaterAtIndex([7, 8, 9], [1, 2, 3]) => 0
    numGreaterAtIndex([7, 8, 9], [9, 0, 53]) => 2

problem_data.brief_description: Check if a list of ints is sorted
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of ints and returns True if the list is sorted from lowest to highest, and false otherwise. Assume that an empty list is sorted. For example: 
    isSorted([1,2,3,4,99, 123, 2342]) => True
    isSorted([1,2,3,4,999, 50, 2342]) => False
    isSorted([]) => True

problem_data.brief_description: Swap values using a dictionary
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list of strings named items and a dictionary named d with strings as both the keys and the values. Return a new list containing all of the strings from items , but if any string in items occurs as the key in d replace it with the value. For example: 
    swapper(['ab','bc','dog'], {'ab':'xyz'}) => ['xyz', 'bc', 'dog']

problem_data.brief_description: Reverse dictionary by making keys values and vice-versa
problem_data.description:
Write a function that reverses a dictionary, by switching the keys to values, and the values to keys. Because the keys of a dictionary must be unique, you may assume that the values are also unique. For example: 
    reverseDictionary({1:2}) => {2:1})
    reverseDictionary({1:2, 3:4}) => {2:1, 4:3})
    reverseDictionary({1:2, 3:4, 7:7, 9:6}) => {2:1, 7:7, 4:3, 6:9})

problem_data.brief_description: Count the number of matching values in a list
problem_data.description:
Write a function that takes a list and an item x, and returns the number of times that x occurrs in the list. Use recursion in your implementation. For example: 
    recCount([1,2,3], 2) => 1
    recCount([], 16) => 0
    recCount([4,3,2,1,4,5,6,3], 4) => 2

(min-width:992px){.modal-lg{width:900px}}</style></head><body>
<h2 id="bracket-validator">Bracket Validator</h2>
<p>You're working with an intern that keeps coming to you with JavaScript code that won't run because the braces, brackets, and parentheses are off. To save you both some time, you decide to write a braces/brackets/parentheses validator.</p>
<p>Let's say:</p>
<ul>
<li>'(', '{', '[' are called "openers."</li>
<li>')', '}', ']' are called "closers."</li>
</ul>
<p>Write an efficient function that tells us whether or not an input string's openers and closers are properly nested.</p>
<h4 id="examples-">Examples:</h4>
<p><code>"{ [ ] ( ) }"</code> should return <code>True</code></p>
<p><code>"{ [ ( ] ) }"</code> should return <code>False</code></p>
<p><code>"{ [ }"</code> should return <code>False</code></p>
<p>Simply making sure each opener has a corresponding closer is not enough — we must also confirm that they are correctly ordered.For example, <code>"{ [ ( ] ) }"</code> should return <code>False</code>, even though each opener can be matched to a closer.</p>
<p>We can do this in <code>O(n)</code> time and space. One iteration is all we need!</p>
<h4 id="bonus-">Bonus:</h4>
<p>In Ruby, sometimes expressions are surrounded by vertical bars, "|like this|". Extend your validator to validate vertical bars. Careful: there's no difference between the "opener" and "closer" in this case—they're the same character!</p>

</body></html>

<h1 id="add-a-closed-interval">Add a Closed Interval</h1>
<p>Write a function which takes as input a list <code>myl</code> of disjoint closed intervals with integer endpoints,
sorted by increasing order of left endpoint, and an interval <code>interval</code>, and returns the union of <code>interval</code>
with the intervals in A, expressed as a union of disjoint intervals. </p>
<h1 id="example">Example</h1>
<p><code>[(1, 2)]</code>, <code>(3, 4)</code>-> <code>[(1, 2), (3, 4)]</code><br><code>[(3, 4)]</code>, <code>(1, 2)</code>-> <code>[(1, 2), (3, 4)]</code><br><code>[(0, 2), (3, 6), (7, 7), (9, 12)]</code>, <code>(1, 8)</code> -> <code>[(0, 8), (9, 12)]</code></p>

</body></html>

(min-width:992px){.modal-lg{width:900px}}</style></head><body>
<h1 id="merging-sorted-arrays">Merging sorted arrays</h1>
<p><em>GTG 14.1</em><br>Given sorted arrays <code>arr1</code> and <code>arr2</code> of lengths <code>n</code> and <code>m</code> respectively, return an array <code>out</code> containing the union of the elements of both arrays, without any duplicates.</p>
<ul>
<li>Use <code>brute force</code> to quickly establish the passing of test cases</li>
<li>Use <code>binary search</code> to search through <code>arr1</code> (the bigger of the two) between inserting the element in <code>arr2</code> into <code>out</code></li>
</ul>
<h1 id="example">Example</h1>
<p><code>[1, 1]</code>, <code>[]</code> -> <code>[1]</code><br><code>[1]</code>, <code>[2]</code> -> <code>[1, 2]</code><br><code>[1, 2]</code>, <code>[2]</code>, -> <code>[1, 2]</code><br><code>[3, 4]</code>, <code>[1, 2]</code> -> <code>[1, 2, 3, 4]</code><br><code>[3, 4, 4]</code>, <code>[1, 1, 2]</code> -> <code>[1, 2, 3, 4]</code><br><code>[1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]</code>, <code>[4, 4]</code> -> <code>[1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8]</code>  </p>

</body></html>

<h3 id="self_converge">self_converge</h3>
<p><code>Goal</code>: Given a number, return the number of iterations it takes to arrive at a derived number that converges on to itself, as per the following routine. Recursion is recommended. </p>
<ol>
<li>Initialize a counter to count the number of iterations</li>
<li>Take any four-digit number, using at least two different digits. (Leading zeros are allowed.)</li>
<li>Arrange the digits in descending and then in ascending order to get two four-digit numbers, adding leading zeros if necessary.</li>
<li>Subtract the smaller number from the bigger number. Let's call this a sequence_number.</li>
<li>Check if the sequence_number (the remainder) from Step 3 equals the orginal number. If not, increment the iteration counter, and go back to step 2 and perform it on the sequence_number.<ul>
<li>If there is a match, then return the count of iterations</li>
<li>If the sequence_number collapses to zero, then return -1 </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="converge-values">Converge values</h3>
<p>While 3-digit numbers converge to the same unique number <code>k</code> which is also 3 digits long, all 4-digit numbers also converge to the same unique value <code>k1</code> which is 4 digits long. However, 5 digit numbers converge to any one of the following values: <code>53955, 59994, 61974, 62964, 63954, 71973, 74943, 75933, 82962, 83952</code>.</p>
<h3 id="example">Example</h3>
<p><code>1234</code>  ->   <code>3</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">4321</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1234</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">3087</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">8730</span> - <span class="hljs-number">378</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">8352</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">8532</span> - <span class="hljs-number">2358</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">6174</span> /   
   <span class="hljs-number">7641</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1467</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">6174</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// same as previous</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>414</code> -> <code>4</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">441</span> - <span class="hljs-number">144</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">297</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">972</span> - <span class="hljs-number">279</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">693</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">963</span> - <span class="hljs-number">369</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">594</span> /
<span class="hljs-number">4.</span> <span class="hljs-number">954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">459</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">495</span> /
   <span class="hljs-number">954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">459</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">495</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// same as previous</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>50000</code> -> <code>3</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">50000</span> - <span class="hljs-number">5</span>      =  <span class="hljs-number">49995</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">99954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">45999</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">53955</span> /  <span class="hljs-preprocessor"># first </span>
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">95553</span> - <span class="hljs-number">35559</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">59994</span> /
   <span class="hljs-number">99954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">45999</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">53955</span> /  <span class="hljs-preprocessor"># 2nd time</span>
</code></pre>

</body></html>

(min-width:992px){.modal-lg{width:900px}}</style></head><body>
<h3 id="self_converge">self_converge</h3>
<p><code>Goal</code>: Given a number, return the number of iterations it takes to arrive at a derived number that converges on to itself, as per the following routine. Recursion is recommended. </p>
<ol>
<li>Initialize a counter to count the number of iterations</li>
<li>Take any four-digit number, using at least two different digits. (Leading zeros are allowed.)</li>
<li>Arrange the digits in descending and then in ascending order to get two four-digit numbers, adding leading zeros if necessary.</li>
<li>Subtract the smaller number from the bigger number. Let's call this a sequence_number.</li>
<li>Check if the sequence_number (the remainder) from Step 3 equals the orginal number. If not, increment the iteration counter, and go back to step 2 and perform it on the sequence_number.<ul>
<li>If there is a match, then return the count of iterations</li>
<li>If the sequence_number collapses to zero, then return -1 </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="converge-values">Converge values</h3>
<p>While 3-digit numbers converge to the same unique number <code>k</code> which is also 3 digits long, all 4-digit numbers also converge to the same unique value <code>k1</code> which is 4 digits long. However, 5 digit numbers converge to any one of the following values: <code>53955, 59994, 61974, 62964, 63954, 71973, 74943, 75933, 82962, 83952</code>.</p>
<h3 id="example">Example</h3>
<p><code>1234</code>  ->   <code>3</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">4321</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1234</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">3087</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">8730</span> - <span class="hljs-number">378</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">8352</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">8532</span> - <span class="hljs-number">2358</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">6174</span> /   
   <span class="hljs-number">7641</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1467</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">6174</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// same as previous</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>414</code> -> <code>4</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">441</span> - <span class="hljs-number">144</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">297</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">972</span> - <span class="hljs-number">279</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">693</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">963</span> - <span class="hljs-number">369</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">594</span> /
<span class="hljs-number">4.</span> <span class="hljs-number">954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">459</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">495</span> /
   <span class="hljs-number">954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">459</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">495</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// same as previous</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>50000</code> -> <code>3</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">50000</span> - <span class="hljs-number">5</span>      =  <span class="hljs-number">49995</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">99954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">45999</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">53955</span> /  <span class="hljs-preprocessor"># first </span>
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">95553</span> - <span class="hljs-number">35559</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">59994</span> /
   <span class="hljs-number">99954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">45999</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">53955</span> /  <span class="hljs-preprocessor"># 2nd time</span>
</code></pre>

</body></html>

<h3 id="self_converge">self_converge</h3>
<p><code>Goal</code>: Given a number, return the number of iterations it takes to arrive at a derived number that converges on to itself, as per the following routine. Recursion is recommended. </p>
<ol>
<li>Initialize a counter to count the number of iterations</li>
<li>Take any four-digit number, using at least two different digits. (Leading zeros are allowed.)</li>
<li>Arrange the digits in descending and then in ascending order to get two four-digit numbers, adding leading zeros if necessary.</li>
<li>Subtract the smaller number from the bigger number. Let's call this a sequence_number.</li>
<li>Check if the sequence_number (the remainder) from Step 3 equals the orginal number. If not, increment the iteration counter, and go back to step 2 and perform it on the sequence_number.<ul>
<li>If there is a match, then return the count of iterations</li>
<li>If the sequence_number collapses to zero, then return -1 </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="converge-values">Converge values</h3>
<p>While 3-digit numbers converge to the same unique number <code>k</code> which is also 3 digits long, all 4-digit numbers also converge to the same unique value <code>k1</code> which is 4 digits long. However, 5 digit numbers converge to any one of the following values: <code>53955, 59994, 61974, 62964, 63954, 71973, 74943, 75933, 82962, 83952</code>.</p>
<h3 id="example">Example</h3>
<p><code>1234</code>  ->   <code>3</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">4321</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1234</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">3087</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">8730</span> - <span class="hljs-number">378</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">8352</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">8532</span> - <span class="hljs-number">2358</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">6174</span> /   
   <span class="hljs-number">7641</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1467</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">6174</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// same as previous</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>414</code> -> <code>4</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">441</span> - <span class="hljs-number">144</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">297</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">972</span> - <span class="hljs-number">279</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">693</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">963</span> - <span class="hljs-number">369</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">594</span> /
<span class="hljs-number">4.</span> <span class="hljs-number">954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">459</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">495</span> /
   <span class="hljs-number">954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">459</span> =  <span class="hljs-number">495</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// same as previous</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>50000</code> -> <code>3</code></p>
<pre><code class="lang-c"><span class="hljs-number">1.</span> <span class="hljs-number">50000</span> - <span class="hljs-number">5</span>      =  <span class="hljs-number">49995</span> /   
<span class="hljs-number">2.</span> <span class="hljs-number">99954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">45999</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">53955</span> /  <span class="hljs-preprocessor"># first </span>
<span class="hljs-number">3.</span> <span class="hljs-number">95553</span> - <span class="hljs-number">35559</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">59994</span> /
   <span class="hljs-number">99954</span> - <span class="hljs-number">45999</span>  =  <span class="hljs-number">53955</span> /  <span class="hljs-preprocessor"># 2nd time</span>
</code></pre>

</body></html>
To pass a class, you must get a grade of 60 or higher. Write a function to determine whether the given grade will get a pass.
Write a function that will alert the user about whether it is the weekend yet, based on the current day (provided as a string).
Write a function that determines whether the given positive number has exactly two digits.
Write a function that returns true if only one of the two given parameters is true. (Note- the normal ‘or’ operator returns true when both are true.)
A number is only considered negative if it’s less than 0. Write a function that determines whether the given number is negative.
Write a function which, when given a continent name, returns whether that continent is connected to any other continents or not. (Hint- only two continents are entirely surrounded by ocean!).

You just bought avocados at the grocery store! They won’t be ripe for another two days, but after those two days you’ll need to eat them within a week, before they go bad. Write a function that takes the number of days that have passed to determine whether or not you can eat avocados.
Write a function that returns true if exactly two of the three given parameters are true.

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-1
problem_data.description: Write a function which determines whether the given input is over 9000!

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-2
problem_data.description: In python you can compare strings like you compare numbers (using alphabetical order); for example, the string ‘abcd’ is less than the string ‘zyxw’. Write a function that determines whether the given string starts with a letter in the first half of the alphabet (before ’N’). (Hint: you can assume that the first letter will be uppercase).

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-3
problem_data.description: A letter is lowercase if it comes between ‘a’ and ‘z’. Write a function that determines whether the given letter is lowercase.

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-4
problem_data.description: A person is generally considered to be a teenager between the ages of 13 and 18. Write a function which determines whether the given age is both teenaged and not prime. (Hint: only 13 and 17 are primes in that range).

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-5
problem_data.description: A person can only drink alcohol if they’re 21 or older and aren’t planning on driving. Write a function which, given these two variables, determines whether or not you can drink.

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-6
problem_data.description: The candy shop around the corner is open between 1pm and 7pm every day, except for Wednesdays, when it’s closed. Write a function to tell whether or not it’s open given the current time (expressed as the hour) and day of week.

problem_data.brief_description: exercise-7
problem_data.description: Write a function which determines whether a number is within five of another number.
